Reject the ALLE TE/MN P ower acquisition by CPPIB & GIP (BlackR ock) / PUC Dock et Number 24-198
FromConnie Lou S wanson <connielou55@everyactioncustom.com>
DateThu 8/7/2025 8:20 AM
To Staff, CA O (PUC) <consumer.puc@state.mn.us>
[You don't often get email from connielou55@everyactioncustom.com. Learn why this is important at
h t t p s : / / a k a . m s / L e a r n A b out S e n d e r I d e n t i f i c a t i on ]
This message may be from an external email source.
Do not select links or open attachments unless verified. Report all suspicious emails to Minnesota IT
Services Security Operations Center.
________________________________
Dear Minnesota Public Utilities Commission,
I am writing to ask you to reject the sale of ALLETE/Minnesota Power to the Canada Pension Plan
Investment Board (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP), which is owned by BlackRock, the
world’s biggest private equity firm. This acquisition is not consistent with the public interest.
The recent “settlement agreement” reached between the Department of Commerce and Minnesota
Power and their private equity backers does very little to address the deep risks this potential deal poses
to Minnesota Power customers, employees, and the Minnesota public at large. Putting a handful of weak
conditions on a fundamentally dangerous bargain does not make it “in the public interest.”
The companies pushing this deal utterly failed to make their case—there is no proof that this funding is
needed, nor that new owners will support the clean energy transition we need. There is no basis upon
which to approve this deal, and a long record of harms and risks supporting denial.
I expect Commissioners to listen to the majority of voices in this proceeding, including the Administrative
Law Judge, who recognize this deal for what it is: a perilous gamble that hands Minnesota’s energy
future over to rapacious private equity interests at the expense of customers, workers, and local business
and industry.
Do your duty under Minnesota law to look out for the best interests of Minnesota Power customers,
Minnesotans across the state, and the public as a whole, and reject the acquisition of ALLETE/Minnesota
Power by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners. Greater
Minnesota communities need consumer protection and accountable institutions, just like your
community.
Sincerely,
Connie Lou Swanson
Deerwood, MN 56444-8786
connielou55@gmail.com

Dear Minnesota Public Utilities Commission,
I am writing to ask you to reject the sale of ALLETE/Minnesota Power to the Canada Pension Plan
Investment Board (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP), which is owned by BlackRock, the
world’s biggest private equity firm. This acquisition is not consistent with the public interest.
The recent “settlement agreement” reached between the Department of Commerce and Minnesota
Power and their private equity backers does very little to address the deep risks this potential deal poses
to Minnesota Power customers, employees, and the Minnesota public at large. Putting a handful of weak
conditions on a fundamentally dangerous bargain does not make it “in the public interest.”
This business deal to sell Minnesota Power (MP) to CPP and GIP has no intent to provide benefits to MP's
customers, it is strictly a process to increase shareholder earnings.  There is absolutely no reason, or
incentive, for these shareholders involved in this transaction to do anything that will benefit Minnesota
Power's customers.  There is one very good reason for them to take advantage of their ownership
position, which is to increase the profits of MP by increasing the costs to MP's customers.  This same
process has been repeated time and again in other industries with the only benefits coming to the
shareholders at the expense of the customer.
The companies pushing this deal utterly failed to make their case—there is no proof that this funding is
needed, nor that new owners will support the clean energy transition we need. There is no basis upon
which to approve this deal, and a long record of harms and risks supporting denial.
I expect Commissioners to listen to the majority of voices in this proceeding, including the Administrative
Law Judge, who recognize this deal for what it is: a perilous gamble that hands Minnesota’s energy
future over to rapacious private equity interests at the expense of customers, workers, and local business
and industry.
Please do your duty under Minnesota law to look out for the best interests of Minnesota Power
customers, Minnesotans across the state, and the public as a whole, and reject the acquisition of
ALLETE/Minnesota Power by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure
Partners. Greater Minnesota communities need consumer protection and accountable institutions, just
like your community.
Sincerely,
Michael Overend
Cohas set, MN 55721-8960
drmoverend@gmail.com

STATE OF MINNESOTA  
 
BEFORE THE  
MINNESOTA PUBLIC UTILITIES COMMISSION  
 
 
In the Matter of the Joint Petition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan Investm ent Board and Global 
Infrastructure Partners  
Pension Plan Investment Board    PUC Docket No. E -015/PA -24-198 
 IBEW Local 31  -  
EXCEPTIONS TO THE ADMINISTRATIVE LAW JUDGE’S REPORT
 
Pursuant to the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission’s July 18, 2025, Notice  of ALJ 
Report and Opportunity to File Exceptions, the International Brotherhood of Electrical 
Workers (IBEW)  Local 31 respectfully submits the following Exceptions to the 
Administrative Law Judge’s (ALJ) Findings of Fact, Conclusions, and Recommendations 
in the above -captioned matter. These Exceptions are grounded in our position as the 
exclusive representative for many of the skilled utility workers at Minnesota Power and reflect our interest in ensuring that any transfer of ownership does not diminish labor protections or operational stability.  
I. EXCEPTION TO FINDING G – LABOR IMPACTS
 
A. The ALJ’s citation of broad private equity data lacks application to the regulated 
utility context.  
 
The ALJ cites a 2019 University of Chicago and Harvard Business School study, which 
found that employment declines by 13 percent over two years following take -private 
buyouts of publicly listed firms, and that the bankruptcy risk for such firms is ten times higher than firms that were not taken private. While these statistics are academically 
credible and contextually useful, they do not reflect the distinct regulatory structure or 
capital recovery model applicable to Minnesota Power.1 
This study does not consider the unique protections embedded in the regulated utility environment. The acquiring entities , GIP and CPP Investments , are infrastructure- focused 
investors that theoretically rely on the financial health and long- term operational stability 
of the utility in order to realize returns via cost recovery mechanisms regulated by the Commission. As such, it would be counterproductive to destabilize Minnesota Power, the vehicle through which those regulated returns are recovered.  
B. Labor  risk and the role of oversight   
 
The ALJ concludes that there is credible evidence of potential labor risks arising from 
private equity acquisitions, including the possibility of layoffs or erosion of worker protections. IBEW Local 31 acknowledges this concern but emphasizes that Minnesota’s 
regulatory structure , including the Commission’s oversight authority and statutory 
obligations , provides an important safeguard. Should adverse impacts to the union 
workforce materialize, IBEW Local 31 affirms the importance of the Commission as a meaningful forum to raise and resolve such concerns. The Commission's visible ongoing responsibility to ensure fair treatment of both workers and consumers offers a critical layer of protection under Minnesota law . 
C. The ALJ’s reference to SunPower’s bankruptcy illustrates the contrast between 
unregulated and regulated energy sectors.  
 
 
1 ALJ Report, Finding 276, Section G, Labor Impacts, citing 2019 University of Chicago and Harvard 
Business School study  
In highlighting the recent SunPower bankruptcy, the ALJ draws a relevant distinction 
between the largely unregulated, non- unionized clean energy industry and the highly 
regulated environment of a public utility.2 SunPower’s collapse underscores the risks 
faced by workers and customers when regulatory oversight is absent. Unlike firms operating in competitive clean energy markets, Minnesota Power operates under statutory and regulatory structures that embed accountability and safeguard reliability, fiscal 
discipline, and labor protections.  The retention of assets by a utility, particularly within 
the Minnesota regulatory framework, enables this crucial oversight to occur.  We concur 
with Judge McKenzie ’s finding that the SunPower model  differs  greatly from Minnesota 
Power ’s structure  but wish to emphasize the pressing need to focus meaningful 
investment in the regulated sector . 
D. The clean energy industry’s labor record further supports regulated utility 
investment models.  
 
As reflected in public comments and policy research, the clean energy sector is frequently 
associated with lower wages, diminished worker protection s, and business models that 
prioritize profit maximization in unregulated markets.  In contrast, the entry of private 
capital into the regulated utility space offers an opportunity to reinforce and extend 
protections , including workforce stability, collective bargaining, and long -term 
infrastructure investment tied to enforceable standards.  
II. COMMENT ON DOC STIPULATIONS – WORKFORCE AND 
ENFORCEMENT MEASURES  
 
 
2 ALJ Report, Finding 473.  
IBEW Local 31 applauds the Minnesota Department of Commerce (DOC) for securing 
meaningful stipulations and enf orceable language that serve the public interest. In 
particular, we strongly support:  
 the Commission’s retained authority to impose penalties under Minn. Stat. § 216B.57 for 
violations of the stipulations or Commission orders;  the requirement for annual 
compliance reporting for a ten- year period post -closing, which must include:  
o Workforce levels  
o Labor relations  
o Statu s of collective bargaining agreements.  
 These commitments reflect a balanced and transparent approach that strengthens oversight while acknowledging the vital role of workers in utility performance and public service delivery .
3 
III. CO NCLUSION 
 IBEW Local 31 respectfully takes exception to the ALJ’s findings as they relate to labor impacts and the presumed risks associated with private equity investment. We believe the record demonstrates that the potential for long- term financial stability and responsible 
infrastructure investment under the proposed transaction outweighs the generalized and unproven risks cited in opposition. With the thoughtful stipulations secured by the Department of Commerce , including enforceable reporting and oversight mechanisms 
 
3 DOC Stipulations, Section III, Reporting and Enforcement Provisions.  
that prioritize labor stability and accountability , we support the transaction’s approval as 
structured. 
 Dated:   August 4, 2025  Respectfully submitted,  
 
Kristin Renskers  
 
/s/   Kristin Renskers 
Kristin Renskers 
Business Manager/Financial Secretary  
IBEW Local 31  
2002 London Rd, Ste 105 Duluth, MN 55812   PHONE:  218.969.2201 
EMAIL:  krenskers@ibew31.com

On Behalf Of: North Central States Regional Council of Carpenters/IUOE Local 49
content:
CORRECTED: Comments from Operating Engineers Local 49  
and North Central States Regional Council of Carpenters  
August 4, 2025  
Mr. Mike Bull  
Acting Executive Secretary  
Minnesota Public Utilities Commission 121 7th Place East, Suite 350  
St. Paul, MN 55101  
Re: Letter of Support – Docket No. PA -24-198 – Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan 
Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners  
Dear Commissioners,  
On behalf of the International Union of Operating Engineers Local 49 and the North Central States 
Regional Council of Carpenters, which represent over 25,000 members across Minnesota, we fully 
support the Settlement between the Department of Commerce, ALLETE/ Minnesota Power, Global 
Infras tructure Partners and Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (DOC Settlement) .  
We believe that the DOC S ettlement and acquisition represent significant benefits for Minnesota workers, 
customers, and local communities, particularly in terms of job security, investment in local infrastructure, 
and workforce stability. Our unions concur with the Department of C ommerce and other parties who 
reviewed the transaction to ensure continued secure investment, sustained affordable energy, and 
assistance with driving clean energy initiatives.  
The buyers, CPP Investments and GIP, have publicly committed to honoring existing workforce 
agreements, keeping ALLETE locally managed, maintaining high labor standards, and collaborating on 
future infrastructure needs to support both reliability and decar bonization. This commitment respects 
existing workforce agreements, maintains high labor standards, and works collaboratively to address 
Minnesota’s future energy and infrastructure needs. Based on the direction the owners plan to take this 
acquisition, we  anticipate positive impacts for jobs, workforce stability, and local surrounding 
communities. This deal will continue to uphold commitments to a union workforce, safe workplaces and 
investment in local infrastructure as Minnesota continues to pursue an am bitious clean energy and grid 
modernization goal.  
This acquisition will also facilitate immediate savings and significant benefits to Minnesota Power’s 
customers and communities. With the inclusion of a rate freeze and forgiveness program, it is consistent 
with the public interest according to the DOC and  many stakeholders. Approval of the transaction is 
necessary to secure the capital and experienced ownership required for Minnesota Power to maintain its 
service commitments and support robust regional economic activity.  
In summary, both the Carpenters and Operating Engineers Local 49 urge the Minnesota Public Utilities 
Commission to reject the ALJ’s recommendations and approve the DOC settlement, emphasizing the 
broader value to Minnesota’s workforce, electric reliability, and affordability. We urge the PUC to 
approve the transaction as being in the public interest and beneficial for Minneso ta workers and 
communities.  
Thank you for your consideration. Please do not hesitate to contact us if you require further information. 
Sincerely,  
Richard Kolodziejski, Director of Government Affairs, North Central States Regional Council of 
Carpenters  
Nathan Runke, Regulatory and Political Affairs Coordinator, International Union of Operating Engineers 
Local 49

to raise surcharges on other ratepayers, many of whom may also be suﬀering. This is 
a pow erful opportunity to draw shareholders into the work of funding and sustaining 
arrearage relief and CARE aﬀordability beneﬁts for Minnesota Power customers.  
 
5. Lastly, ECC would note that placing the numerical value of this concession in propor�on to the valua�on of the macro valua�on of the transac�on obscures the micro -level potency of this concession. For those receiving this arrearage 
forgiveness, it may very well mean a lessen ed need to choose between medicine, 
food and u�li�es. These are working families across the Company’s service territory who are s�ll clawing their way out of a once -in-a-genera�on cost of living crisis with 
even more uncertainty on the horizon.

Red Lake Na�on . 4F5 As recently as 2024, we lobbied before the Commission for a disconnec�on

nothing inherent in the ownership structure of any of these en��es precluded the need for vigilance and advocacy on behalf of low -income customers.  
ECC does not deny nor discount that the proﬁt expecta�ons of the Partners  exist in cross -

aﬀordable, equitable and reliable service to Minnesotans of every income, it is  in large part  
because advocates have leveraged the enforcement mechanisms of the regulatory compact to

to use nego�a�ons over the price of acquisi�on to undermine the credibility of any asser�on of a values -based transac�on.

ECC’s support of the Setlement – and the acquisi�on as a whole  – is not rooted in blind faith in 
the inten�ons of the Partners . Rather, we see a perennial need for vigilance on behalf of low -
income customers within the guardrails and protec�ons of the regulatory compa ct. While there

Dan McConnell , President         •  DON MULLIN , Secretary  Treasurer         •  TOM DICKLICH , Executive  Director  
           353 W. 7th STREET, ROOM 103, ST. PAUL,  MN 55102     •      TEL (651) 287- 9999     •     W ww.MnTrades .org 
 
 
 
 
 August 4, 2025  
 
Mr. Mike Bull  
Executive Secretary  
Minnesota Public Utilities Commission  
121 7th Place East, Suite 350  
St. Paul, MN 55101   
 RE: Comments in the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by 
Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners (Docket 24 -198)  
 Mr. Bull,  
 
On behalf of over  70,000 skilled construction workers represented by the unions affiliated with 
the Minnesota Building and Construction Trades Council, I am writing to once again share our 
support for the proposed purchase of ALLETE, Inc. by infrastructure investment funds  managed 
by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners, and to express our appreciation for the efforts of the Minnesota Department of Commerce to negotiate additional public benefits and protections. We initially supported the transaction 
because we believe it is the best path for Minnesota Power to secure the capital needed to 
build a safe, reliable and increasingly carbon -free grid using local union labor. Our support has 
only been strengthened by the set tlement between the DoC, ALLETE, CPPIB, and GIP which 
comprehensively addresses the concerns raised by opponents and delivers tangible benefits to 
Minnesota  Power customers and the state.  
 
The men and women represented by the Minnesota Building Trades have counted on 
Minnesota Power to provide affordable, reliable power and economic opportunity in Northeast 
Minnesota for more than 100 years. During that time, the company’s ownership structur e has 
changed, but the commitment to customers and union workers has not.  
 
The first question Minnesota Building Trades and our affiliated unions asked ourselves after the 
announcement was how a utility owned by a couple of large infrastructure fund investors might 
differ from one owned by Wall Street stockholders. Based on our i nitial review of the proposal 
and our experience with the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission, we came to the conclusion 
that the sale would have no impact on the way Minnesota Power operates on a day -to-day 
basis, while greatly strengthening the utility ’s capacity to attract capital and support badly -
needed economic growth in its service territory.  
 
Dan McConnell , President         •  DON MULLIN , Secretary  Treasurer         •  TOM DICKLICH , Executive  Director  
           353 W. 7th STREET, ROOM 103, ST. PAUL,  MN 55102     •      TEL (651) 287- 9999     •     W ww.MnTrades .org 
 
 
 
 
 Since that time, Minnesota Building Trades unions and members have participated in the 
contested case proceedings and public hearings, and nothing we have seen or heard there has 
weakened our conviction that the sale is in the best interest of customers and workers. While 
we know that change can be scary, nothing about the transaction affects the ability of the Public Utilities Commission to set rates and allowed capital structures, or to approve or deny 
investment on the front end or rate and rider recover y on the back end. The controls in place 
after the transaction will be the same as those that exist today, as will the financial incentive to meet the expectations and requirements established by the Legislature and Public Utilities 
Commission.  
 
It’s no secret why ALLETE pursued a private acquisition after more than seven decades as a 
publicly -traded company. In 2023, the State of Minnesota required every utility serving 
Minnesota customers to achieve 100% carbon -free power by 2050. For Minnesota Power, 
which relies heavily on coal- fired power despite the utility’s leadership in renewable 
generation, meeting that mandate means unprecedented investment in transmission, 
renewable generation, batteries and other low - and zero -carbon technology. The sc ale of 
needed investment is far beyond anything ALLETE has done in the past or is capable of doing as a stand -alone company  
 
The elected leaders of Minnesota’s Building Trades unions understand the challenge, because 
they sit on boards that manage hundreds of billions of dollars in pension fund assets and are 
affiliated with international unions that collectively invest more than $500 billion in stocks, bonds, infrastructure, real estate and over investment vehicles. We recognize that a $6 billion 
company seeking an additional $5 billion in capital over just five years looks like a potentially 
risky proposition even before considering Minnesota Power’s unique exposure to risks 
associated with ebb and flow of mining activity.  
 
The Minnesota Building Trades supported Minnesota’s 100% clean energy when it passed in 
2023, despite the fact that achieving the mandate will impact the livelihood of members who 
maintain coal -fired power plants and other legacy infrastructure. For this r eason, it has been 
disappointing to see a number of organizations and institutions that say they support climate 
progress oppose the transaction without providing any realistic alternative for financing 
Minnesota Power’s clean energy transition.  
 
We are especially troubled by claims that the utility could meet the need for additional capital 
by relying more on customers, third -party providers or other utilities as suggested by the DoC, 
Office of the Attorney General and others. While some have trie d to stir up opposition to the  
 
Dan McConnell , President         •  DON MULLIN , Secretary  Treasurer         •  TOM DICKLICH , Executive  Director  
           353 W. 7th STREET, ROOM 103, ST. PAUL,  MN 55102     •      TEL (651) 287- 9999     •     W ww.MnTrades .org 
 
 
 
 
 acquisition by inaccurately describing the transfer of a utility from one set of private investors 
to another as “privatization,”
1 the real threat of deregulation and privatization comes from the 
outsourcing of the utility’s obligation to serve to third parties that are not fully under the 
control and oversight of the Public Utilities Commission.  
 
Minnesota Power already employs all of  the tools suggested by opposing parties to provide the 
Public Utilities Commission with a full set of options, and to provide customers with the best 
value. Minnesota Power regularly solicits third -party bids for energy generation, encourages 
residential customers to install rooftop solar and partners with utilities like Great River Energy 
to build and finance transmission projects. But in each case the utility’s capability of delivering these projects on its own helps to ensure that the priorities of the utility’s customers are not 
subordinated to the interests of third parties.  
 
Minnesota Power has already experienced the limitations of even modest levels of reliance on 
third parties. The utility struggled for years to develop a demand response product that was 
acceptable to both large industrial customers and the Public Utilities  Commission due to the 
cost of compensation that customers expected in exchange for curtailing their demand.  
 
Similarly, Minnesota Power saw its plan for development of solar generation in the service 
territory delayed when the low -bidder Cypress Creek failed to deliver the 10 MW Blanchard 
Solar project because the company was unable to secure site control. The ut ility’s solar 
requirement was only met when Minnesota Power filed a 20 MW self- build proposal, and the 
Commission recently approved an additional 200 MW of utility -built, utility -owned solar in 
Cohasset and Royalton as the best option to meet the need iden tified in the current Integrated 
Resource Plan. Just today, the utility filed a petition seeking approval to build and own 200 MW 
of wind in North Dakota utilizing Minnesota Power’s upgraded HVDC line. Like Boswell and 
Regal Solar, Longspur Wind emerged as  the lowest -cost option for utility customers  
 
If Minnesota Power is unable to secure adequate capital to continue proposing utility -financed 
projects or to do so cost -effectively, customers and the public interest will suffer in important 
ways. The potential consequences of a capital shortage are pote ntially severe. Capital shortfalls 
could create deployment delays that could threaten the utility’s ability to meet requirements, 
maintain reliability and/or take advantage of favorable market conditions and avoid 
unfavorable conditions. Further capital shortfalls will almost certainly result in higher costs for  
 
 
1 https://curemn.org/blog/take -the-power -back/   
 
Dan McConnell , President         •  DON MULLIN , Secretary  Treasurer         •  TOM DICKLICH , Executive  Director  
           353 W. 7th STREET, ROOM 103, ST. PAUL,  MN 55102     •      TEL (651) 287- 9999     •     W ww.MnTrades .org 
 
 
 
 
 customers by reducing competition and giving third parties more leverage to extract premiums 
in cases where the utility could have provided a more cost -effective option.  
 Workers will also suffer from capital constraints, first, as a result of project cancellations and 
delays; and second, because capital shortfalls will limit Minnesota Power’s ability to set and 
enforce requirements that advance the workers’ interests and t he state’s values. A decade ago, 
large wind and solar energy projects built to serve Minnesota utilities created very few jobs for 
union or local workers, as documented by North Star Policy Institute and  Local Jobs North 
because the third- party developers responsible for construction hired contractors that relied 
heavily on non -union out- of-state workforce.
2  
 
Today, similar projects are creating hundreds of jobs for union and local workforce, in large part 
because utilities like Xcel Energy and Minnesota Power began to simultaneously pursue more 
self-build projects, and to make use of local and/or union labor a  requirement for Power 
Purchase Agreement providers that were previously reluctant to make any such commitments. 
Neither utility could have moved the market without having the option of building their own 
projects if third -party providers balked. The same is true for efforts to increase participation of 
people of color, women and veterans in the workforce and as vendors, which have made much 
greater strides through utility -owned than through third -party -owned projects. This risk is not 
just hypothetical: in Minnesota Power’s Longspur Wind petition, the utility identifies difficulty 
securing assurances on labor protections as a problem in dealings with one or more potential PPA providers.
3 
 
The dynamic is even worse for customer- owned generation, where the state’s values in the 
area of fair compensation, respect for workers’ rights, and workforce inclusion play little or no 
role, because neither the utility nor the Public Utilities Commission  can easily tell customers 
how to build their own projects. As a result, industries such as rooftop solar installation are dominated by low -wage work and lack the sort of inclusive career pathways adopted by 
Building Trades unions. Given the poor economies  of scale associated with most distributed 
generation projects, increasing Minnesota Power’s reliance on them would push up rates,  
 
2 https://northstarpolicy.org/catching- the-wind -the-impact -of-local -vs-non-local -hiring- practices -on-construction -
of-minnesota -wind -farms/ ; https://www.localjobsnorth.org/reports   
3  “The Company initially intended to announce multiple selected projects as a portfolio, however, negotiations 
stalled and material changes occurred in the project list including inability to provide certain assurances on labor 
and cost protections  to maintain that project’s compliance with fundamental requirements of the approved RFP 
terms.” (Emphasis added) https://www.edockets.state.mn.us/documents/%7BE0367698 -0000 -CE10 -9781 -
01A328D04471%7D/download?contentSequence=0&rowIndex=1    
 
Dan McConnell , President         •  DON MULLIN , Secretary  Treasurer         •  TOM DICKLICH , Executive  Director  
           353 W. 7th STREET, ROOM 103, ST. PAUL,  MN 55102     •      TEL (651) 287- 9999     •     W ww.MnTrades .org 
 
 
 
 
transfer wealth from lower to higher -income customers best able to take advantage of these 
programs, and exchange high -quality jobs on utility -scale projects for lower- quality jobs on 
distributed projects. The proposed transaction will help to ensure that MInnesota Power 
customers are never forced to overpay for energy resources owned by third parties that take our money but won’t live up to our values.  
 
The agreement between the ALLETE, investors and DoC improves greatly upon a transaction 
that already advanced the public interest, turning a home run into a Grand Slam. The 
settlement includes more than a dozen significant concessions on the part of ALLETE  and 
investors, including a reduction in the utility’s Return on Equity, a one -year moratorium on rate 
increases, new service quality penalties, the addition of independent directors to ALLETE’s 
board, strict limits on the ability of investors to issue div idends, and a $50 million investor- paid 
clean energy advancement fund. These terms represent substantial public benefits and they 
should resolve any remaining concern that ownership by private infrastructure funds could 
somehow destabilize Minnesota  Power’s finances or undermine the Commission’s ability to 
oversee and regulate the utility’s operations.  
 
Given the clear necessity for better access to capital and the robust framework negotiated with 
the DoC, it is disappointing that the Administrative Law Judge not only failed to grasp the public 
interest case for the transaction but doesn’t seem to have tried. To the contrary, the ALJ seems 
to have gone out of her way to exclude every inconvenient fact, bit of testimony and public comment from her summary of the record. As one example among many, the ALJ wholly 
ignores the direct and  rebuttal testimony of L IUNA expert witness Erin Bryant, while treating 
the testimony of an opposing witness with less relevant experience as gospel truth.  
 
Where she was unable to simply exclude information favorable to the transaction, such as in 
her summary of public comments, the ALJ denigrates its value by attacking the motive and 
competence of supporters. Her claim that supporters largely repeated compan y talking points 
and her suggestion that many may have been inappropriately influenced by the utility clearly demonstrate her lack of respect not just for supporters – including many Building Trades 
members – but for the public process. The Minnesota Building Trades and our affiliated unions 
have participated in hundreds of public hearings and comment processes through the years, and we have never  seen a state official responsible for conducting the proceeding demonstrate 
this level of bias or contempt for the public. Given the ALJ’s conduct and choice to exclude 
evidence that she found disagreeable from the record, we do not believe any weight sho uld be 
given to her findings, conclusions or recommendations. While in our experience Commissioners always do th eir own homework, in this case they need to do so without any assistance from the 
ALJ in order to get an objective picture of the case.  
 
Dan McConnell , President         •  DON MULLIN , Secretary  Treasurer         •  TOM DICKLICH , Executive  Director  
           353 W. 7th STREET, ROOM 103, ST. PAUL,  MN 55102     •      TEL (651) 287- 9999     •     W ww.MnTrades .org 
 
 
 
 
It is clear to us that approval of the proposed transaction will bring significant benefits to 
Minnesota Building Trades members in the form of more and lower- cost investments in job -
creating projects, coupled with preservation of the utility’s ability to provide the capital needed 
to provide safe, reliable, affordable, and increasingly clean power. And pursuant to the agreement negotiated by the DoC, Building Trades members served by Minnesota Power will 
also benefit from lower electric rates, better prote ctions and debt forgiveness for those who 
have fallen behind.  
 
On the other hand, a decision to deny approval could have catastrophic consequences, 
destroying job opportunities on upcoming projects and forcing the utility to spend more money 
chasing capital and less keeping rates affordable and service reliable. In th e face of possible 
recession, trade wars, and Federal actions that seem designed to make our electricity dirtier and more expensive, we cannot afford to gamble Northern Minnesota on speculative and half -
baked suggestions that Minnesota Power can get by pinching pennies and leaving 
infrastructure build -out to others. We ask the Commission to make the right choice and 
approve the transaction, and we thank you for your time and consideration.  
 
Thank you,  
 Tom Dicklich  
Executive Director  
MN Building and Construction Trades Council

INITIAL COMMENT  
  
 
The Large Power Intervenors (“LPI”) respectfully submit  this initial comment in response 
to Notice of C omment Period  on the Proposed Settlement  (“Notice”) issued by the Minnesota 
Public Utilities Commission (“Commission”  or “MPUC” ) on July 18, 2025, in the above 
referenced docket. 1  The Notice poses five questions for comment:  
1. Is the proposed Settlement between the Department of Commerce and ALLETE 
consistent with the public interest within the meaning of Minn. Stat. § 216B.50?  
2. Has the proposed Settlement addressed the questions addressed to the Administrative Law Judge in the Commission’s Order of October 7, 2024?  
3. Does the Acquisition proposal as modified by the Settlement agreement provide appropriate protections to low -income customers and customers from marginalized 
communities?  
 
1  Notice of Comment Period on the Proposed Settlement  at 1 (Jul. 18, 2025) (eDocket No. 20257-
221154- 01). 
2 
 4. Are there conditions that should be imposed on this transaction in addition to those 
that were included in the S ettlement, and if so, what are those conditions?  Please 
describe the additional condition and support its inclusion. 
5. Are there other issues or concerns related to this matter?  
Per its responses to these questions, and f or the reasons described herein, LPI respectfully urges 
the Commission to deny the proposed settlement in its entirety. 
I.  INTRODUCTION 
 On Friday afternoon, July 11, 2025, two business days prior to the  anticipated  issuance of 
the Administrative Law Judge’s (“ALJ”) Findings of Fact, Conclusions of Law, and 
Recommendations (“ALJ Findings”)  in this proceeding, the Department of Commerce 
(“Department”), Minnesota Power, Canada Pension Plan Investments, and Global Infrastructure Partners (together, “the Partners”), jointly filed (as the “Settling Parties”)  a proposed settlement 
stipulation (“Settlement”), in the above -captioned docket.  The Settlement purports to offer “a 
series of additional commitments resp onsive to issues and concerns raised by the Department that 
ensure that the Acquisition is consistent with the public interest.”
2  LPI is troubled by this 
characterization, and the corresponding social media efforts by the Partners  to advance the 
 
2  Settlement Stipulation Between the Minnesota Department of Commerce, ALLETE, Inc. d/b/a 
Minnesota Power, Canada Pension Plan Investment Board, and Global Infrastructure Partners at 2  (Jul. 11, 
2025) (eDocket No. 20257- 220879- 01) (“Settlement Stipulation”) .  
3 
 Settlement, which are simply  more statements that are entirely inconsistent with the record , that 
the Commission should disregard.3   
To be sure , the record developed over the course of a year demonstrates that  the proposed 
Settlement includes little, if any, incremental benefit to the list of commitments the Partners agreed 
to over the course of the proceeding  and included in the Partners’ proposed findings submitted to 
the ALJ .  These commitments were not persuasive to six  of the Parties then, and five  of the 
Intervenors now .  Nor were they persuasive to the ALJ, which the ALJ addressed  in detail in the 
ALJ Findings.  T he Settlement is , in fact, s ubstantively and legally flawed by largely restating 
Commitments rejected in the 283 Findings of Fact that the ALJ made after a year of record 
development and evidentiary proceedings that concluded the proposed Acquisition is not in the public interest.  Furthermore, the Settlement is procedurally flawed, especially considering that the Settling Parties refused to respond to LPI’s requests for information regarding its benefits.  Even 
if the Commission sees some benefit to the Settlement the likes of which LPI does not, no record 
exists upon which the Settlement could be approved.  The Commission should therefore deny  it 
and the proposed Acquisition, and require Minnesota Power to provide an accounting of the cost 
incurred pursuing the transaction.   
 
3  See, e.g., ALJ Findings  (Public)  at 38, P 180, n.339 (“At various times throughout this proceeding,

parties, like the Partners, engaging in complex transactions, like the Acquisition, rely on written 
agreements.  The Commission should do the same. ”) (emphasis added)

 II.  ANALYSIS  
A. The Settlement as Proposed is Not Consistent with the Public Interest . 
Minnesota Statute § 216B.50 requires Commission authorization for any public utility to 
“sell, acquire, lease, or rent any plant as an operating unit or system in this state for a total 
consideration in excess of $1,000,000, or merge or consolidate with another public utility or 
transmission company operating in this state.”  As noted by the ALJ, the longstanding requirement 
to obtain this approval is for the petitioners  to establish, by a preponderance of the evidence, that 
the proposed transaction “is consistent with the Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 public interest standard.”4  
Further, if the Commission finds the proposed action consistent with the public interest, § 216B.50 requires “it shall give its consent and approval ….”   In applying that standard, the Commission has 
sought evidence of tangible benefits to ratepayers.
5  While the Partners advocate for a lower 
standard, the ALJ correctly concludes , in recommending rejection of the Proposed Acquisition:  
The parties have argued that the public interest requires the  
Commission find that the deal either produces net benefits or, 
alternatively, avoids net  harm. The proposed deal is inconsistent 
with the public interest under either standar d because it results in net 
harm to the public interest.6 
Therefore, LPI review s the marginal additional commitments offered in the Settlement 
through the same lens – that is, regardless of the interpretation of how to satisfy the public interest

R. 1400.7399 subp. 5).

 standard under Minnesota law, whether the Settlement meets even the low bar of eliminating harm 
to the public interest.  For reasons further explained below, the Settlement does not offset the harms 
of the Proposed Acquisition or  offer anything not already required by Minnesota law.   
Additionally, the Settlement fails to explicitly address the questions addressed to the Administrative Law Judge in the Commission’s Order of October 7, 2024, in this docket. 
B. The Conditions Proposed in the Settlement are Repetitive of Those Rejected in the

prehearing orders, t he Settling Parties refused to engage and were not  willing to respond to basic 
discovery to ease concerns around how the procedural posture of the Settlement, or  what it offered 
 
36  Settlement Stipulation at 4 (see terms 1.14, 1.43) (estimating that a Commission final order will 
not be produced until early 2026).  
37  ALJ’s Findings  and Recommendations  at 73.  
38  Appendix A contains the information requests issued by LPI. 
15 
 distinct from existing commitments that had been previously unacceptable to the Department.39    
The Department’s and Partner’s position is extremely disappointing.  The discovery deadline was 
set at the beginning of the contested case process, as a common practice to limit discovery and distraction during the evidentiary hearings.  None of the part ies anticipated the production of new 
information, let alone a proposed settlement on the eve of ALJ Findings, well after the conclusion of the evidentiary hearings.  Parties should not be precluded from asking questions related to a new, substantive document introduced after evidentiary hearings have concluded.  The Partners 
bear the burden of proof in this proceeding.  By not responding, the Partners are underscoring their 
inability to meet this burden.  Furthermore, the Partners’  refusal to engage with L PI regarding its 
questions only perpetuates the litigious and untransparent practices the Partners exhibited during the proceeding and exacerbates LPI’s concerns around transparency and the willingness of the 
Partners to work with Minnesota Power customers moving forward.  
III.  CONCLUSION 
For the reasons provided herein above, t he Settlement is procedurally and legally flawed 
and fails to rescue the Proposed Acquisition from being entirely inconsistent with the public 
interest .  Absent the Partners coming forward with material ratepayer protections, LPI cannot 
support the Settlement.  As drafted, the Settlement does not comport with the public interest and 
should be denied.

Dear Mr. Moratzka:  
On July 14, 2025, the Large Power Intervenors served the Department of Commerce with 
discovery requests 500 through 504 in connection with the above -referenced matter . These 
requests, however, are untimely. The deadline for serving discovery was March 26, 2025. (First 
Prehearing Order ¶ 12.) Moreover, the Minnesota chapter 1400 rules that would otherwise permit 
LPI to engage in timely discovery are no longer applicable given that jurisdiction over the matter 
has returned to the Public Utilities Commission. See Minn. R. 1400.8300 ; Minn. Admin. Proc. § 
7.4.1 (3rd ed.). Finally, even if LPI’s  discovery was timely and permitted by the applicable rules , 
several questions attempt to obtain privileged work -product or otherwise inadmissible settlement 
communications . 
Although the Department will not be responding to LPI’s untimely discovery, the 
Department appreciates that there is great interest in the stipulation and questions about how the 
Settling Parties intend for various provisions to be construed. LPI, for example, asked the 
Department which stipulation provisions are new,  and which were previously proposed by 
Petitioners. That information can be found in footnote three of the stipulation . In another instance, 
LPI asked the Department about the composition of the post -Acquisition board. To clarify, the  
board will have fourteen  directors. The Partners will select ten directors based on their respective 
ownership  interests . The Partners will select three directors by agreement . The final director will 
be ALLETE’s CEO. Of the thirteen non -CEO directors, six of them will meet the NYSE’s 
definition of independence and the Partners will appoint the remaining seven directors to represent 
their respective interests  consistent with their fiduciary obligations to ALLETE under Minnesota 
law.  
If LPI has  other questions about the meaning of stipulation provisions, please contact me 
by telephone  or e-mail. While discovery is not permissible  at this point in the contested -case

MPUC Docket No. E-015/PA-24-198 
Dear Mr. Moratzka: 
On July 14, 2025, Minnesota Power, Global Infrastructure Partners, and Canada 
Pension Plan Investment Board (the Petitioners) received what you have characterized 
as discovery regarding the settlement stipulation between the Petitioners and the 
Department of Commerce in Minnesota Public Utilities Commission Docket 24-198. 
Pursuant to the Administrative Law Judge’s prehearing order, the deadline to issue 
discovery requests in this proceeding was March 26, 2025. The questions sent on July 
14, 2025, are well beyond that deadline. Further, several of your questions appear to 
seek legal conclusions, which would not be appropriate to provide through a 
discovery/information request process. 
The Petitioners recognize, however, that there is substantial interest in the settlement, 
and that several of your questions appear to seek information about what the settlement 
means or how it works. More generally, we are pleased to provide the information below 
in order to address and resolve your questions.  
As we first reviewed your questions, we identified that the language in the agreement 
addresses a number of the questions raised. For example, with respect to a comparison 
of the settlement terms to other commitments in this matter, that information is included 
in the settlement in Footnote 3, which highlights additional benefits from the settlement 
beyond those previously offered by Petitioners, such as service quality commitments, a 
LPI Initial Comment on Proposed Settlement 
Appendix C 
Page 1
Mr. Moratzka 
July 24, 2025 
Page 2 
  
  $50 million Clean Firm Technology Fund, and enhancements to other commitments, 
such as enforceability, to name a few.  
 
You also asked for information regarding the state resident independent directors, which 
is described in Section 1.23 of the settlement. As explained there, ten directors will be 
appointed by the Partners with each Partner having the right to appoint one director to 
the Board for every 10 percent ownership of ALLETE, Inc., three directors will be 
appointed by agreement among the Partners, and the last seat will be filled by the CEO. 
The CEO’s board seat will not count as a director from the State of Minnesota or State 
of Wisconsin, so the non-CEO directors must include state resident directors to satisfy 
the terms of the settlement.1  
 
Other questions you have raised focus on the scope of the Commission’s regulation of 
Minnesota Power or related matters. The settlement includes a number of commitments 
that recognize, and are consistent with, key regulatory principles, while building on 
those principles to provide further benefits to customers.  For example, with respect to 
your questions regarding the Company’s capital plans, as you are aware, the 
Commission does not approve capital plans. Rather, it is and will continue to be the 
obligation of the utility (as with other Minnesota utility companies) to develop, finance, 
and execute a capital plan, and the Commission reviews the prudence of any regulated 
investments the utility proposes to make via resource plans, certificates of need, rate 
cases, and other cost recovery proceedings. That said, the settlement provides an 
enforceable commitment to provide capital to support Minnesota Power’s 5-year capital 
investment plan, subject to such prospective reasonable and prudent plan adjustments.  
 
In addition, Commitment 1.12 in the settlement expressly addresses debt-related 
concerns raised by parties to the proceeding.  Furthermore, it remains the case that the 
utility will have the burden to prove that its proposed cost of debt is reasonable and that 
its proposed cost of equity is appropriate, based upon market data and analysis 
available at the time, in any future rate proceeding. This also means other parties will 
have the opportunity to provide their own views on reasonable authorized levels of debt, 
capital structure, and rates of return, and the Commission will ultimately make those 
decisions for Minnesota Power. Commitments 1.12 and 1.41 build on these existing 
principles and require Minnesota Power to prove the absence of transaction-related cost 
of debt increases and other costs, respectively. These commitments are distinct from 
and in addition to the standard burden of proof.  
 
We also wanted to note that Commitment 1.33, related to access to books and records 
of Minnesota Power, expands on existing requirements for Minnesota Power by 
 
1 In addition, the New York Stock Exchange definition of “independent,” as set forth in NYSE Rule 303A.01, which 
will apply to certain of the directors as set forth in the settlement, can be found on its website, located here: 
https://nyseguide.srorules.com/listed-company-manual/09013e2c8503fca9 .   
LPI Initial Comment on Proposed Settlement 
Appendix C 
Page 2
Mr. Moratzka 
July 24, 2025 
Page 3 
  
  increasing access to books and records of entities in the post-acquisition structure up to 
and including Alloy Parent.  
 
You also asked about the estimated date conditions will be met for Minnesota Power’s 
return on equity (“ROE”) to be reduced to 9.65 percent following close of the Acquisition 
and for the other settlement benefits to take effect. Commitment 1.14 in the Settlement 
provides that the ROE adjustment will take effect “the first full month after both of the 
following have occurred: (i) the close of the Acquisition and (ii) when the order of the 
Commission becomes final.” The timing of the Commission order will be established by 
the Commission; as such, we cannot specifically provide dates.  Beyond that, the 
Petitioners hope to close the Acquisition as soon as practicable, which will allow the 
many benefits of the settlement to begin accruing to customers and the State of 
Minnesota. 
 
In addition, you asked some questions regarding the Company’s plans related to land 
sales and funding of the CARE program. Commitment 1.46 does not alter land sale 
proposals in Docket No. E015/PA-20-675, but rather seeks to accelerate the return of 
these funds to customers and addresses the manner in which the funds are returned to 
customers (which was not previously determined).  LPI and other stakeholders will have 
the opportunity to respond to the Company’s proposal under Commitment 1.46.  
Commitments related to energy affordability provide binding commitments that benefit 
consumers, including Commitment 1.47, which ensures the budget for CARE will not be 
reduced, regardless of circumstances in the future, and further demonstrates the 
alignment between the Company and the Partners to serve customers in the region.  
 
Lastly, the Partners’ willingness to finance a Clean Technology Fund, agree to a rate 
case stay-out, finance customer arrearages, reduce the ROE, and remove other cost 
items from rates means neither LPI customers nor any other customers will be asked to 
pay for those items in the future, providing significant cost savings.  The Company has 
also agreed to service quality commitments with penalties that the Company – not 
customers – would pay if not met. These binding, enforceable commitments are a 
material benefit of the settlement.   
 
These commitments will benefit all customer classes, including industrial classes, but 
cannot take effect unless the acquisition is approved and until the settlement takes 
effect. Once the acquisition is approved, it will be consummated and, as set forth in 
Commitment 1.26 of the settlement, the definitive governance documentation regarding 
ALLETE will be consistent with the settlement as approved by the Commission.  And, 
ultimately, the Commission will determine what the Company’s rates and costs to 
customers will (or will not) be.

content:
Setting the Record  Straight:  The Case  for ALLETE's  Access  to Capital 
and Clean Energy Leadership  
Policy without  capital is  a plan without  power.  
 
Introduction  
ALLETE has long been a trusted provider of reliable energy and a committed partner in advancing 
clean energy initiatives. As the energy industry undergoes rapid transformation, driven by the 
imperative  to adopt  sustainable  practices, the  role of access to capital  becomes critical. This  position 
paper outlines why access  to new  capital is essential  for ALLETE's continued  progress toward  clean 
energy, its connection to affordable rates and reliable service, and the  necessity of returns for capital 
providers.  
ALJ  Concerns 
The concerns raised by the Administrative Law Judge (ALJ) do not reflect the economic or 
operational  realities  of today’s  energy sector;  particularly  for a company  like ALLETE that is striving 
to balance a clean energy transition with reliable service and ratepayer affordability. Suggesting that the acquisition by Canada Pension Plan (CPP) Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP) does not deliver clear benefits to the public overlooks a critical truth: without new capital and 
strategic partners, ALLETE risks falling behind in the infrastructure race requ ired to meet both state 
mandates and regional expectations for energy resilience and decarbonization.  
Criticism of the transaction’s impact on ratepayers also appears to misunderstand the direct 
connection between capital access and rate stability. Delaying or denying access to long -term, patient 
capital increases the likelihood that ALLETE will be forced to rely on shorter -term, higher -cost 
financing or defer  needed  investment  altogether. Both  scenarios ultimately  push  costs  onto 
customers, either through higher maintenance expenses from aging infrastructure or regulatory penalties for failing to meet clea n energy targets. The CPP and GIP investment, by contrast, enables 
a forward - looking capital plan that supports efficiency, scale, and long- term rate moderation.  
Moreover, as part of this agreement, Minnesota Power is locking in immediate financial relief for 
customers by freezing base electric rates for the next year —delivering rate certainty at a time when 
families  and businesses  need  it most.  The company  is also lowering  its authorized  Return  on Equity 
from 9.78% to 9.65% post -close, a decision that directly reduces the cost burden on customers until 
the next formal rate proceeding.  
 
These are not symbolic gestures. These are real, measurable outcomes that benefit customers right 
now. This  approach  reflects  strong,  forward -looking  leadership:  securing the capital  needed  for long-  
term investment while ensuring affordability and predictability today. It is a clear example of how 
responsible utility regulation and strategic private investment can work hand- in-hand to serve the 
public interest.  
Further, the ALJ raises the issue of public benefit , yet this transaction squarely serves the public 
interest. A better -capitalized ALLETE can invest more confidently and expeditiously in projects that 
reduce emissions, improve grid stability, and attract federal and state infrastructure funding. These 
are not theoretical gains. They are practical outcomes that will shape the energy landscape of 
northern Minnesota for decades. Moreover, CPP and GIP’s long- term orientation and infrastructure 
expertise provid e oversight and accountability that is arguably more aligned with public interest than 
the pressures of quarterly reporting and shareholder short -termism in the public markets.  
Finally, it is worth underscoring that returns to investors like CPP and GIP are not antithetical to 
community  benefit. They  are the mechanism  by which capital  flows into  regions  like ours  in the first 
place. The alternative is not a better offer; it is no offer. Blocking transactions on philosophical grounds, without a clear economic alternative, risks eroding confidence in Minnesota as a place where essential infrastructure investments can succeed. That is not just a missed opportunity for ALLETE. This is  a step backward for the entire region.  
Let’s  review  the full picture.  
Why  New  Access to Capital  is Critical for ALLETE's  Clean  Energy  Transition  
Transitioning to clean  energy is  a capital -intensive  endeavor. The development  of renewable  energy 
infrastructure, such as wind farms, solar arrays, and energy storage systems, requires significant 
upfront investments. Additionally, aging grid infrastructure must be modernized to support these 
clean energy sources and ensure reliability.  
Canada  Pension Plan  (CPP)  Investment  Board  
The CPP Investment Board, established in 1997 by an Act of Parliament, manages Canada Pension 
Plan investments  with a focus  on maximizing  long- term returns without undue  risk of loss. The CPP 
is accountable to Parliament and to federal and provincial ministers, however, it operates 
independently guided by an independent Board of Directors. The investment -only mandate helps 
ensure the Fund’s long- term sustainability and financial security for Canadians.  
Global  Infrastructure Partners  (GIP) 
GIP aims to deliver attractive returns by investing in infrastructure assets that empower economies and societies across  the globe.  Its strategy is  driven  by an extensive  global  network of  relationships, 
a disciplined investment approach, and comprehensive operational expertise that focuses on 
improving businesses for the long- term.  
ALLETE's ability to access new  capital  through its partnership with  the Canada Pension Plan 
Investment  Board  (CPP) and  Global  Infrastructure  Partners (GIP) is vital for several  reasons:  
• Scaling Renewable Energy Projects: To meet both regulatory mandates and community expectations  for cleaner  energy, ALLETE needs  the financial  capacity  to accelerate  
large - scale renewable projects.  
• Innovation in Technology:  Investment  in cutting -edge  technologies, such as energy  
storage and smart grids, is essential to maintain reliability as renewable energy sources are 
integrated.  
• Risk Management: New capital provides the financial buffer needed to manage risks 
associated  with clean  energy development, such as project  delays,  fluctuating energy prices, 
and technological challenges.  
The Connection Between  Access  to Capital,  Affordable  Rates,  and Reliable  Service  
Energy providers like  ALLETE must balance  three  priorities: transitioning  to cleaner energy 
sources, maintaining reliable service, and keeping rates affordable for customers. Access to 
capital is the critical link between these priorities:  
• Economies  of Scale  Reduce  Costs:  With  access to substantial  capital,  ALLETE can build 
larger, more efficient renewable projects, driving down the per -unit cost of energy 
production. This ultimately helps keep customer rates affordable.  
• Preventing Costly Delays:  Without sufficient  capital,  projects  are delayed  or scaled  back, 
which can lead to higher costs over time as compliance with clean energy mandates 
becomes more urgent.  
• Maintaining  Reliability: Transitioning to renewable energy sources can present  
challenges to grid reliability, particularly during peak demand. Investment in grid  
modernization, energy storage, and backup systems  ensures that  reliability is  not 
compromised as the energy mix evolves.  
In short, access to capital allows ALLETE to make the necessary investments now, avoiding higher costs and  reliability challenges in the future, while  protecting ratepayers from  the financial burdens  of 
inaction.  
Why  Providers  of Capital  Need  a Return  
The partnership with CPP and GIP brings more than just capital —it brings strategic expertise and 
long- term alignment with ALLETE's  clean  energy goals.  However,  it is important  to recognize  that 
these entities, as providers of capital, require a return on their investment. Here’s why:  
• Capital Has a Cost:  Investors  like CPP and GIP  allocate resources to  projects  that generate 
a return. Without the incentive of returns, these entities would direct their capital elsewhere, leaving ALLETE without the financial means to achieve its goals.  
• Risk-Reward Balance: Transitioning to clean energy  carries risks, including market 
volatility,  regulatory changes,  and technological  uncertainties.  The returns  investors 
receive are compensation for assuming these risks.  
• Alignment with ALLETE's Success: CPP and GIP are not short -term investors. Their 
commitment to ALLETE is built on a shared vision of long- term growth and community 
impact.  Their  returns are tied to ALLETE's success  in delivering reliable,  affordable,  and 
clean energy.  
The returns generated by CPP and GIP are not a detriment to ALLETE's customers —they are a 
necessary component of ensuring ALLETE can secure the funding required to build a cleaner, more reliable energy future.  
Conclusion 
Access to new capital is a pivotal cornerstone of ALLETE's ability to transition to clean energy 
while maintaining affordable rates and reliable service. Partnerships with experienced investors like 
CPP and  GIP provide  the financial  resources, strategic expertise,  and long- term alignment needed 
to meet these challenges. Furthermore, the return on investment required by capital providers is a 
reasonable and essential part of this equation, ensuring that ALLETE can continue to attract the 
funding necessary to serve its customers and communities.  
This partnership represents an opportunity to advance ALLETE's leadership in clean energy, 
benefiting  both  the environment and the  economic  well-being of  the communities  it serves.  Ensuring 
access to capital today secures a sustainable and prosperous energy future for tomorrow.  
Policy without  capital  is a plan without  power.  
 
Author  
Matt Baumgartner, MBA,  CFA Candidate , President  & CEO , Duluth  Area  Chamber  of Commerce  
Co-signe d 
April Jesperson , President  & CEO , Grand Rapids Area Chamber of Commerce  
Kimberly Parmeter, IOM , MBA, President & CEO , Hermantown Area Chamber of Commerce  
Purva Watten, President & CEO , Little Falls Chamber of Commerce

1  Dear Commission,  The Private Equity Stakeholder Project is a nonprofit watchdog organization with a mission to bring transparency and accountability to the private equity industry and help empower impacted communities and investors. Our organization provided expert testimony in this case on behalf of the intervenor CURE, opposing the private equity acquisition of ALLETE and its subsidiary Minnesota Power. Our organization has reviewed the proposed settlement between the Department of Commerce and ALLETE and found that the proposal does not adequately resolve the concerns we raised about the private equity buyout of Minnesota Power by GIP and BlackRock. It also leaves room for financial engineering tactics outlined in the recently released ALJ Findings of Facts - “If the Partners employ financial engineering strategies to increase the returns they earn from their investments in Alloy, the likely result is extra debt that causes ALLETE’s cost of capital to rise, which would result in rates that are higher than they otherwise would have been absent the proposed acquisition.”1 Therefore, we do not find the settlement consistent with the public interest within the meaning of Minn. Stat. § 216B.50.  The capital commitments outlined in the settlement do not address concerns outlined in our testimony about the rate of return GlP anticipates receiving for this acquisition. In pitch materials to investors, GIP advertised that the fund being used to acquire Minnesota Power will target a 15-20% annual return (IRR) before fees.2 This is around double the return (8.36%) that publicly-traded US utilities have generated over the past decade.3  In addition, GIP seeks to collect a 5-7% annual cash yield (i.e., dividend) from portfolio companies it acquires. The settlement provides a modest return on equity (ROE) reduction of 9.78 to 9.65 percent until Minnesota Power’s next rate case.4 The settlement then proposes a roughly one-year rate freeze, until November 1, 2026, with no rate-protections for customers beyond that.5 As outlined in our testimony, there is a risk of bill hikes after private equity acquires a utility, even if there is a “freeze” for one year. In the UPPCO example, the company applied for a rate increase6 the year following an acquisition by a private equity firm, leading to unaffordable  1  State of Minnesota Office of Administrative Hearings, “Findings Of Fact, Conclusions Of Law, And Recommendations”, Accessed July 29, 2025, https://www.edockets.state.mn.us/documents/%7B70F30F98-0000-CF5C-BB62-491162C889B0%7D/download?contentSequence=0&rowIndex=24  2 Erick Russell to Members of the Investment Advisory Council, February 3, 2023, p.194  3  Based on a 10-year annualized total return of 8.36%, Dow Jones U.S. Utilities Index, accessed Jan 24, 2025. https://www.spglobal.com/spdji/en/indices/equity/dow-jones-us-utilities-index/?currency=USD&returntype=T-#overview  4  Settlement Stipulation Between The Minnesota Department Of Commerce, Allete, Inc. D/B/A Minnesota Power, Canada Pension Plan Investment Board, And Global Infrastructure Partners at 1.14 https://www.edockets.state.mn.us/documents/%7B60E8FA97-0000-CE3D-9DF6-C6E70C864E2F%7D/download?contentSequence=0&rowIndex=27  5  Settlement Stipulation Between The Minnesota Department Of Commerce, Allete, Inc. D/B/A Minnesota Power, Canada Pension Plan Investment Board, And Global Infrastructure Partners at 1.43 https://www.edockets.state.mn.us/documents/%7B60E8FA97-0000-CE3D-9DF6-C6E70C864E2F%7D/download?contentSequence=0&rowIndex=27  6 “Rate Debate”, Pioneer Tribune, June 23, 2016, https://www.pioneertribune.com/articles/rate-debate/  
      
  2  bills.7 UPPCO filed to increase rates again three years later by nearly $10 million.8 The Michigan Attorney General intervened in the rate case urging the PSC to reduce that number to $3.5 million saying “UPPCO’s customers have been burdened by extremely high electric rates – some of the highest in Michigan.”9    Finally, transparency around and mitigation of the cost of debt increases above current levels, as outlined in stipulation 1.12, does not go far enough to reduce potential debt loads that are generally placed on private equity-owned portfolio companies and leaves ratepayers vulnerable to paying back those debts in many circumstances, meaning that under these terms, Minnesotans would still be at risk of negative financial implications resulting from BlackRock and GIP’s takeover. As the ALJ Findings Of Fact, Conclusions of Law, and Recommendations noted, “the Commission lacks authority to force the Partners to take actions such as providing capital to Minnesota Power, retaining employees, making community investments, or withholding dividends. It is also unlikely that the Commission has the vast resources that would be required to monitor compliance with all of the commitments – meaning a violation would likely only become clear after a violation and substantial harm had already occurred.”10   The stipulations outlined in this settlement regarding rates of return, debt, and rate increases are weak. There is still a threat that Minnesota Power’s captive customer base would bear the financial burden of fulfilling private equity’s promises to its investors regarding above-market returns.   Given these outstanding concerns about the cost of capital for ALLETE and risks to ratepayers, we urge the PUC to find this deal not in the public interest and vote not to approve the deal.   Thank you,  Nichole Heil Senior Research and Campaign Coordinator Private Equity Stakeholder Project  7 Matheny, Keith, “Power bills are whoppers for some in Michigan’s U.P.” Detroit Free Press, September 7, 2016, https://www.freep.com/story/news/local/michigan/2016/09/07/power-outrage-electric-bills-upper-peninsula/89593302/  8 Rossman-McKinney, Kelly, “AG Nessel Steps in to Protect UP Customers from Exorbitant Electric Rate Increases” Michigan Department of Attorney General, February 26, 2019, https://www.michigan.gov/en/ag/News/press-releases/2019/02/26/AG-Nessel-Steps-in-to-Protect-UP-Customers-from-Exorbitant-Electric-Rate-Increases  9 Ibid. 10 State of Minnesota Office of Administrative Hearings, “Findings Of Fact, Conclusions Of Law, And Recommendations”, Accessed July 29, 2025, https://www.edockets.state.mn.us/documents/%7B70F30F98-0000-CF5C-BB62-491162C889B0%7D/download?contentSequence=0&rowIndex=24

To Whom It May Concern,  
The Salvation Army Northern Division submits the following public comments to the Minnesota Public Utilities 
Commission regarding the proposed settlement with the Department of Commerce In the Matter of the Petition of 
Minnesota Power for Acquisition of AL LETTE by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure 
Partners (MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198).  
We write to support a proposed financial contribution described in the proposed settlement agreement (pgs. 9 -10, 
paragraph 1.48):  
“The Partners will provide a financial contribution with the objective to significantly reduce residential arrears to pre-COVID -19 balances or lower, an outcome that would benefit all Minnesota Power customers while providing 
account balance relief to the most economically challenged residential customers.” 
Salvation Army Northern Division is dedicated to doing the most good in our communities. The HeatShare initiative is a needs -based heat assistance program offered at most Salvation Army operation centers in Minnesota. It is 
available to low -income seniors,  those living with a disability that prevents them from maintaining a steady 
income, and anyone experiencing an unexpected financial emergency. Furthermore, HeatShare is a safety net for 
Minnesotans who have been declined by other governmental assistance programs and is typically the last resort 
for help with past due heat bills. As many as 4,000 households are helped annually through the HeatShare 
assistance program.  
Currently, financial support for the program comes from optional HeatShare donations by ratepayers, as well as 
local utility companies, other organizations, and individual donors. However, with a program budget of just $1.2 
million, the need is substantial ly greater than what the current funding can cover.  
Salvation Army Northern Division also helps people access resources through the Low -Income Home Energy 
Assistance Program (LIHEAP). However, that program’s funding is uncertain for Federal Fiscal Year 2026.  
We believe additional resources, like the contribution described in the proposed settlement agreement, would 
help low -income people in our communities pay for essential utility services and give some much -needed relief as 
they try to balance limited budget s to meet their everyday needs. We submit these comments in support of the 
proposed financial contribution by the partners and would gladly assist with outreach to raise awareness about 
this additional resource.         
 
Thank you,  
 
Ana Gonzalez, LSW  
Divisional HeatShare  
The Salvation Army Northern Division

On Behalf Of: Center for Energy and Environment and Clean Energy Economy Minnesota
content:
August 4, 2025  
 
Mike Bull , Acting  Executive Secretary  
Minnesota Public Utilities Commission  
121 7th Place East, Suite 350  
St. Paul, MN 55101  
 
RE: Center for Energy and Environment and Clean Energy Economy Minnesota ’s Initial 
Comments in the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota  Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by 
Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners  
 
Docket N umber:  E015/PA -24-198 
 
Mr. Bull, 
 
Center for Energy and Environment (CEE)1 and Clean Energy Economy Minnesota (CEEM)2 
(jointly CEE/CEEM) submit  the following initial comments in response to the Notice of 
Comment Period issued by the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission (Commiss ion) on July 18 , 
2025 , in the above -referenced proceeding  regarding the proposed acquisition of ALLETE3 by the 
Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPPIB) and Global Infrastructure Partners  (GIP)  
(Acquisition) , and the proposed settlement filed July 11, 2025, by the Minnesota Department of 
Commerce (Department) , ALLETE , CPPIB, and GIP  (Settlement) . These comments do not 
respond to the Notice of Comment Period issued by the Commission on July 18, 2025, regarding 
exceptions to the Administrative Law Judge report.  
CEE/CEEM appreciate the substantial  work conducted by parties in this proceeding  to assess 
whether the proposed Acquisition is consistent with the public interest  as defined under Minn. 
Stat. § 216B.50. The proceeding contains an extensive record covering numerous issues related 
to the details  and potential outcomes of the Acquisition, with significant attention being paid to 
the interest of Minnesota Power ratepayers. CEE/CEEM  have reviewed much of the record and  
recognize th e concerns raised from parties  regarding potential ratepayer and other impacts 
 
1 CEE is a 501(c)3 nonprofit organization whose mission is to discover and deploy the most effective energy 
solutions that strengthen the economy and improve the environment , envisioning a health y, carbon -neutral 
economy that works for all people. See mncee.org/mission -values .   
2 CEEM is a 501(c)3 nonprofit organization whose mission is to provide educational leadership, collaboration, and 
policy analysis that accelerates clean energy market growth and smart energy policies , providing the business voice 
for energy efficiency and clean energy in Minnesota. See cleanenergyeconomymn.org/about .  
3 References to Minnesota Power in these comments relate to the utility as a regulated operating division of 
ALLETE.  
 
 
2 
 resulting from the Acqui sition . However, CEE/CEEM argue  the Acquisition , with the stipulations 
contained  in the Settlement , is consistent with the public interest for four  reasons . 
First, t he efforts necessary  to meet the Carbon  Free Standard (CFS) provisions  set forth in Minn. 
Stat. § 216B. 1691  will require  significant  and unprecedented  investment in the electric system  
over the next 15 years. As stated by Minnesota Power and co-signers4 in Joint Reply Briefs filed 
May 29, 2025,  “the Acquisition is essential to Minnesota Power’s plans to comply with the 
Carbon Free Standard”5 through investments “far beyond  [Minnesota Power’s] historic levels ”6 
that “include major transmission, generation, and distribution projects to meet increasing 
customer needs and replace retiring thermal generation, while also maintaining reliability of 
the grid.”7 Although the exact investment levels  needed may be uncertain or disputed by 
parties , the scope of investment needed is clear , and the Acquisition makes that level of capital 
available to Minnesota Power today . 
In additio n, other Minnesota policies provide pathways for  electric and gas utilities to electrify  
end uses typically served by natural gas  and other fuels , such as space heating .8 As the electric 
system decarbonizes under the CFS, electrifying significant portions of the economy is critical to 
meeting the state’s greenhouse gas emission reduction goals under Minn. Stat. § 216H.02 . This 
underscores the need to give electric utilities the tools necessary to invest in decarbonizing the 
electric system while at the same time electrifying customer end use technologies.  
Second, if the Acqu isition is approved , Minnesota Power will still be regulated by the 
Commission under the authority provided by Minnesota Statute s and Minnesota Rules. While 
certain aspects of the company will change, such as governance through the composition of the 
board of directors and capital flowing from private owners instead of public equity markets, 
none of those changes will affect the Commission’s authority, process, or obligation  to regulate 
Minnesota Power’s actions regarding infrastructure investments, resource procurements and 
retirements, capital structure, rates, programs , customer service , and reliability  in a manner 
consistent with the public interest . 
Furthermore, generating or procuring electricity to meet 100 percent of retail customer needs 
from carbon -free energy technology by 2040 is the law,9 with explicit  authority given to the 
 
4 Signers included ALLETE d/b/a Minnesota  Power, CPPIB, GIP, LIUNA MN, IOUE Local 49, IBEW Local 31, and 
Energy CENTS Coalition.  
5 Joint Reply Brief  of Minnesota Power, Canada Pension Plan Inve stment Board, and Global Infrastruc ture Partners . 
Filed May 29, 2025, in Docket No. E015/PA -24-198.  Page 9.  
6 Id. Page 9.  
7 Id. Page 10.  
8 See Minn. Stat. § 216B .241 ( Energy Conservation and Optimization ) and Minn. Stat. § 216B.2427 ( Natural Gas 
Utility Innovation Plan s). 
9 Minn Stat. § 216B.1691, subd. 2(g).  
 
 
3 
 Commission to enforce the law and impose financial penalties for noncompliance.10 The 
Acquisition does not change Minnesota Power ’s legal requirement to comply with Minn. Stat. § 
216B.1691 as regulated and implement ed by the Commission.  
Third, the Settlement filed July 11, 2025, provides significant provisions focused on ratepayer 
protections, workforce and labor stipulations , and commitments to low -income program 
investments, community  contributions, customer service and reliability metrics,  and clean 
energy funds, that were not included in the initial petition .11 These provisions were negotiated 
and established  by the Department and other parties after thorough review and analysis of the 
Acquisition and subsequent discovery and testimony , and provide safeguards against many 
concerns raised in the record.  
Finally , the risk of not approving the Acquisition outweighs the remaining risks associated with 
approving the Acquisition. While no deal is perfect, the Acquisition with the Settlement 
provides the necessary capital needed for Minnesota Power to continue its progress towards 
meeting the CFS, while protecting ratepayers  and investing in clean energy jobs that di versi fy 
northeast Minnesota’s economy, under the full regulatory authority of the Commission. If the 
Commission denies the Acquisition, Minnesota Power will have to seek alternative options to 
fund CFS -related investments that will take significant time and resource s to develop and 
assess, and that will undoubtedly carry their own risks to ratepayers.  
For the above reasons, CEE/CEEM find the Acquisition with the Settlement to be consistent 
with the public interest. Please do not hesitate to contact us with any questions.  
 
Sincerely,  
/s/ Chris Duffrin  
President  
Center for Energy and Environment  
 
/s/ Will Nissen  
Director of Policy  
Center for Energy and Environm ent 
wnissen@mncee.org   /s/ Greg g Mast  
Executive Director  
Clean Energy Economy Minnesota  
 
/s/ George Damian  
Director of Government Affairs  
Clean Energy Economy Minnesota  
gdamian@cleanenergyeconomymn.org
 
 
10 Minn Stat. § 216B.1691, subd. 7.  
11 Settlement Stipulation between the Minn esota Department of Commerce, A LLET E, Inc. d/b/a Minne sota Power, 
Canada Pension Plan Inve stment Board, and Global Infrastructure Partners . Filed July 11, 2025, in Docket No. 
E015/PA -24-198.

DOCKET N UMBER  E015/P A-24-198

the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension 
Plan I nvestment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners  in Docket Number E015/PA -24-198 
on the following persons on the attached Service Lists by:

Post Office at the City of Minneapolis, for delivery by the United States Post 
Office as directed by said envelopes.  
 
_X_ electronic filing  
 
 
 /s/ Will Nissen  
 Will Nissen

445 Minnesota Street, Suite 600, St. Paul, MN 55101 -2125  
Office: (651) 296 -3353 • Toll Free: (800) 657-3787 • Minnesota Relay: (800) 627 -3529  
An Equal Opportunity Employer Who Values Diversity  
 
August 4, 2025 
 
 
Mr. Mike Bull  
Deputy Executive Secretary  
Minnesota Public Utilities Commission  
121 7th Place East, Suite 350  
St. Paul, MN  55101

Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners  
  MPUC Docket  No. E-015/PA -24-198 
 Dear Mr.  Bull : 
  Enclosed and e -filed in the above -referenced matter please find Comments of the Office of 
the Attorney General –Residential Utilities Division.  
  By copy of this letter all parties have been served.  A  Certificate of Service is also enclosed.  
 
Sincerely,  
  /s/ Peter G. Scholtz  
PETER G. SCHOLTZ Assistant Attorney General  
 (651) 757- 1473 (Voice)  
(651) 296- 9663 (Fax)  
peter.scholtz@ag.state.mn.us  
 
 
 
   
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 CERTIFICATE OF SERVICE  
 
Re:   In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners  
  MPUC Docket  No. E-015/PA -24-198 
 
I, JUDY SIGAL, hereby certify  that on the 4th day of August, 2025, I e-filed with eDockets  
Comments of the Office of the Attorney General —Residential Utilities   Division , and served a 
true and correct copy of the same upon all parties  listed on the attached Service List by e -mail, 
electronic submission and/or United States Mail with postage prepaid, and deposited the same in 
a U.S. Post Office mail receptacle in the City of St. Paul, Minnesota.    
  s/ Judy Sigal      
  JUDY SIGAL
